title: 114_hr4586
content: This Act, known as "Lali's Law," amends the Children's Health Act of 2000 to establish opioid overdose reversal medication access and education grant programs under Part E of title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary may grant funds to States for developing standing orders in pharmacies for opioid overdose reversal medication, encouraging dispensing of such medication, implementing best practices for prescribing opioids and discussing medication purposes with patients, and creating training materials for educating the public. The Secretary may grant funds to States for developing standing orders in pharmacies for opioid overdose reversal medication and educating the public on its benefits and availability without a person-specific prescription. Grants are given preference to States without standing orders for opioid overdose reversal medication. The Secretary may grant funds to States for developing standing orders in pharmacies for opioid overdose reversal medication. Grants are given preference to States with a higher per capita rate of opioid overdoses or meeting other criteria deemed appropriate. States can authorize standing orders for community-based organizations, substance abuse programs, or emergency services agencies to acquire and administer the medication. Each State may receive only one grant for a period of 3 years, not exceeding $500,000. States receiving grants under this section must submit detailed applications to the Secretary and report on pharmacy locations dispensing opioid overdose reversal medication. The grant amount is capped at $500,000, with a limitation on public education spending. The section outlines requirements for pharmacies dispensing opioid overdose reversal medication under a standing order, including reporting on doses dispensed and pharmacist training. Definitions for opioid overdose reversal medication and standing order are provided. The section authorizes $5,000,000 for fiscal years 2017 through 2019 for pharmacies to dispense opioid overdose reversal medication under a standing order. Administrative costs are limited to 3 percent of the allocated funds. The Public Health Service Act is amended to reduce the dollar amount by $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2017. This amendment was passed by the House of Representatives on May 12, 2016.
